title: How much it will cost Manchester United to sack Ole Gunnar Solskjaer
text:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer fears for his job at Manchester United (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United will have to fork out around £7million should they decide to sack Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Metro.co.uk understands.

The Norwegian is already fighting for his job at Old Trafford after a dismal start to the season in which United have won just two of their opening eight league games.

Sunday’s 1-0 defeat at Newcastle was the lowest point of Solskjaer’s short reign so far with United managing just three shots on target against the Magpies.

It means United have made their worst start to a league campaign in 30 years and Solskjaer is now fearful that a heavy defeat against Liverpool at Old Trafford after the international break will give the board no option but to sack him.

United face Liverpool at Old Trafford after the international break (Picture: Getty)

Ed Woodward, United’s executive vice-chairman, announced record revenues of £627m in September but that figure included an £19.6m pay-off for Jose Mourinho and his team following their departures in December 2018.

United paid up David Moyes’ contract following his departure in 2014 as a goodwill gesture to the Scot and managerial sackings have proved costly for the Red Devils since Sir Alex Ferguson’s departure in 2013.

As such, Woodward was determined to avoid another costly mistake when he appointed Solskjaer and Metro.co.uk understands the £7m pay-off the Norwegian is in line to receive is the lowest in United’s modern history.

Solskjaer’s wages of around £6m-a-year are well short of the £15m-a-year salary Mourinho received in the north-west and the Norwegian would receive one-year severance pay should he lose his job.

Mike Phelan would be expected to follow Solskjaer out the door, though it remains to be seen whether Kieran McKenna and Michael Carrick would follow.

After the clash against Liverpool, United play four consecutive away games against Partizan Belgrade, Norwich, Chelsea and Bournemouth.

Solskjaer’s side are without a win away from home since February and a failure to emerge from that losing streak in the next four games could push the board into action.
